dt: {bc}to become progressively greater (as in size, amount, number, or intensity)
{bc}to multiply by the production of young

pt: {sc}increase{/sc} {sc}enlarge{/sc} {sc}augment{/sc} {sc}multiply{/sc} mean to make or become greater. {sc}increase{/sc} used intransitively implies progressive growth in size, amount, or intensity
; used transitively it may imply simple not necessarily progressive addition.
{sc}enlarge{/sc} implies expansion or extension that makes greater in size or capacity.
{sc}augment{/sc} implies addition to what is already well grown or well developed.
{sc}multiply{/sc} implies increase in number by natural generation or by indefinite repetition of a process.

et: Middle English {it}encresen{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}encreistre{/it}, from Latin {it}increscere{/it}, from {it}in-{/it} + {it}crescere{/it} to grow {ma}{mat|crescent|}{/ma}
shortdef: to become progressively greater (as in size, amount, number, or intensity)
to multiply by the production of young
